ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt about new ways of viewing photography and expanded upon my Photoshop knowledge.
Honed my technical skills as well as ability to both critique and discuss photography in a more formal sense. I also improved my sense for narrative/storytelling within the frame.
Learning how to read and appreciate photography, photographic theory, and the social issues surrounding photography

I gained an increased knowledge of how to create compelling photographs that have meaning and are able to tell stories. Besides the basic knowledge of working with a camera, editing, and printing, I was exposed to a lot of artist work and photographic theory. It was very beneficial for creating a photographic style and finding sources of inspiration, as well as gaining insight about the process of creating a narrative in my work.

This class taught me how to use a digital camera, how to take good pictures and what elements to focus on when taking photographs. This class also exposed me to many photographers, which was helpful in order to engage in a dialogue with them in my practice.
start to develop some ideas about what makes a good image good, and also critically reflect the ethical issues associated with photo-taking
Learned how to look at photographs differently and how to decide what I photograph

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Danna is amazing and the course is such a welcoming environment where sharing work feels fulfilling. It was amazing! No weaknesses.
Loved the freedom of the course to explore our personal interests, getting feedback to improve the way we tell the stories that are important to us.
It was perfect. The course was informative and productive. An amazing introduction to the discipline that was well structured with critiques, guests lecturers, and theoretical discussions.

I thought Professor Singer was amazing and that we were exposed to a lot of great artists that helped everyone find something they were interested in. The crits were also extremely helpful for creating and improving my work. I think that one improvement could be a stronger emphasis on creative cohesive narratives, but this is hard in only a semester-long course.

Danna is such a personable professor and knows how to engage her students endlessly, whether it is through insightful photo crits,  photo talks with invited speakers or class visits to Haas to see the MFA works of legends. Danna was direct in her crits, which was immensely helpful since her investment in her students was palpable, and her criticism made everyone's work go miles above where they started as the semester progressed. I'm so incredibly thankful to have taken this class with Danna, and hope that she returns to Yale so that other students can be inspired by her and feel less intimidated about taking themselves seriously as artists. She truly is a one-of-a-kind art professor -- I've taken and shopped many art classes. I struggle to think of weaknesses for the class -- maybe we could have done a class trip outside of New Haven? That's not even a complaint -- I just would have loved to hear her speak about photographers' works in New York museums or galleries.

strength: Danna and Emily were very, very supportive of our creative endeavors, especially creative risk-taking! They also made sure to give a lot of attention to each student in the class, and I truly appreciate that! I also got exposed to the work of so many great photographers, and the class field trips to the photo archive at Haas Library and the Yale University Art Gallery were absolutely amazing. 

No weakness
We had great discussion and guest artist

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! It is amazing and you will learn so much and grow as an artist. It is such a welcome reprieve to the academically stressful classes that frequent the semesters here. Take it if you can!
Yes! Loved being able to hone my photography and storytelling ability as well as my personal voice as a photographer.
Definitely. The critic provided an amazing environment to learn in.

Yes! I think that if you have prior experience in photography it is a great next step, but if you don't some of the intro courses would be better. It's still accessible to everyone and it definitely will improve your photography.

I definitely would recommend this class to other students -- both art students and non-art ones. Danna reframes the way we think not only about photography, but also visual culture and how embedded we are in it. Danna helps students key in on main themes in their work that evince more fundamental concerns that underlie their thinking: What does it mean to be first-gen at Yale? How do my different identities shape my worldview? How do I cope with the imminent death of a family member? All of these questions are then productively explored through photography, thanks to Danna's determination to helping us excavate these concerns in our work and then channel our thinking through photography.
ABSOLUTELY!

If you feel like you need a space to work with sequencing and narrative in your photo practice, this is a great place. People with different levels of skill and experience were in my class and it feels like we all grew together by the end of the course.
Definitely!
